questions.question_text:
A company manufactures and sells speaker boxes. The speaker boxes can be silver or black with a basic or upgraded wiring harness assembly.
The speaker box must be created in the item master so that the variables for colors and harness type can be assigned at order entry.
You need to create a new item that supports multiple variables.
What should you do?

discussion.content: D is correct

Selected Answer: D
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-ca/training/modules/create-products-product-masters-dyn365-supply-chain-mgmt/6-product-master-variants

Predefined variant - This type enables the product to be modeled based on the product dimensions, color, configuration, and size. This option is the only one that can be set up directly with product variants. Any combination of the product dimensions is allowed.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D. Why Not Constraint-Based?. Constraint-based configuration (Option B) would require building a configuration model with rules, which is unnecessary here. The speaker box has a small, fixed set of options (4 variants) with no apparent dependencies (e.g., “Black only with Upgraded”), making predefined variants the simpler, more practical choice.

Selected Answer: B
The speaker box must be created in the item master so that the variables for colors and harness type can be assigned at order entry.

It makes the most sense for an item with pretty straight forward dimensions and variant possibilities to be configured with predefined variant. However you cant "assign the variables at order entry" You can only choose released variants. For that reason alone, I'm going with B.
D is correct. You are creating a new items master and configuring it not an order.

Selected Answer: B
Can no be predefined if selected on order

Selected Answer: B
I would say B - If you need to configure on the order line it shouldn't be pre-defined. Also Harness type is not a product dimension. So it should be a configuration model..

comments.content:
Configuration can be used as product dimension : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-ca/training/modules/create-products-product-masters-dyn365-supply-chain-mgmt/6-product-master-variants

The dimension must be specified when product transactions are created, for example when a purchase or sales order line is created.

discussion.content: B:) is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

It should be constraint-based. Predefined variants only allow for configuration, size, color, and style and they need to be set up prior to order entry. Constraint-based allows you to assign the variables on the order without setting up variants & releasing them ahead of time.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct because you can select the variables during transaction in constraint-based but not in predefined.
The correct answer -> D

choices.A: Create a new product. Select predefined variant as the configuration technology.
choices.B: Create a new product master. Select constraint-based configuration as the configuration technology.
choices.D: Create a new product master. Select predefined variant as the configuration technology.
choices.C: Create a new product. Select constraint-based configuration as the configuration technology.

discussion.content:
B. FIFO is correct.

Moving average and Standard cost do not require inventory closing.
FIFO ONLY

Selected Answer: B
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-ca/training/modules/set-up-work-inventory-control/inventory-cost. Microsoft learn clearly states that :The cost method is on the Costing method & cost recognition FastTab. The field is named Inventory model.

The list of available cost methods includes:

FIFO

LIFO

LIFO date

Weighted avg.

Weighted avg. date

Standard cost

Moving average

The first four methodologies require an inventory close at the end of each financial period so that you can settle issues against the receipts. Standard cost and moving average don't require a monthly close.

A See "Inventory close is a required step in the month-end closing procedure for all inventory models except moving average. You will be warned if you try to close a financial period without first performing the inventory close as of the period end date." here https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/supply-chain/cost-management/inventory-close

Inventory close is a required step in the month-end closing procedure for all inventory models except moving average. You will be warned if you try to close a financial period without first performing the inventory close as of the period end date.

Selected Answer: A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/supply-chain/cost-management/inventory-close

2 conflicting answers:
1. In this article is said that "Inventory close isn't required if you use the Standard cost valuation method".
2. But in this article said " Note

Inventory close is a required step in the month-end closing procedure for all inventory models except moving average. You will be warned if you try to close a financial period without first performing the inventory close as of the period end date."
Both of them are https://learn.microsoft.com/

Selected Answer: A
"Inventory close is a required step in the month-end closing procedure for all inventory models except moving average" refer doc.
[Note AX does not require month end for std costing, but D365 does]
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/supply-chain/cost-management/inventory-close

Correct answer is: A. FIFO and Standard Cost items
Only moving average does NOT require the inventory close as the inventory model group1. This is because the moving average method is a perpetual costing method based on the average principle, where the costs on inventory issues do not change when the purchase cost does1. Therefore, inventory close is not required for items using the moving average costing method1. Thank you for pointing that out. I apologize for any confusion caused.

Selected Answer: B
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-ca/training/modules/configure-inventory-management-dyn365-supply-chain-mgmt/17-invent-close-adjust

Consider the following about inventory close:
Inventory close isn't required if you use the Standard cost valuation method.

questions.question_text:
A company has items in inventory with two costing methods: FIFO and Standard.
The company needs to calculate the cost of all items at month end and provide a total inventory value to the finance department.
You need to determine the total value of inventory.
Which costing method requires running the inventory close?

choices.C: LIFO, Moving Average, and Date Weighted Average items

comments.content: It should be product quantity commitment from my perspective

discussion.content: I believe it's NO

The Answer is NO.
the sentence "at a discounted rate of $3.00 per cable" already tells us the cost of each cable.
The Solution Should be:
* Create a purchase agreement of type Product Quantity Commitment.
* Add a Line for C0001.
* Enter the Product Quantity, the Unit Price and the Expiration Date of One Year. ( Net Amount will automatically be Calculated to 15000).

The answer should be No. You need to set up the pricing info and track the agreemeant - with this option you are not really doing this as you would not catch an order being raised for the right value by wrong unit price
A is the correct answer. because it doesn't matter that how you setup. main thing that configuration do the work or not.
This is one of the tricky ones, on first glance it seems like B is the correct one but after thinking about it definitely A is the correct one

Selected Answer: B
Answer B : No - It must be a Product Quantity Commitment link to a specific quantity of product

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-ca/training/modules/configure-use-agreements-dyn365-supply-chain-mgmt/4-purchase-agreements

Product quantity commitment - You purchase a specific quantity of a product.
Product value commitment - You purchase a specific currency amount of a product.
Product category value commitment - You purchase a specific currency amount in a procurement category. The amount can be for a catalog item or a non-catalog item.
Value commitment - You purchase a specific currency amount of any product or products in any procurement category.

Selected Answer: B

The answer is NO. 
Refer question no 15, they gave the same scenario and answered that its a Product Quantity Commitment

Since the solution provided does not define the rate, hence, this answer is incorrect. It should be rather Purchase agreement with qty commitment, with discount rate defined per product with 1 year expiry.

B: NO
Product value commitment – You purchase a specific currency amount of a product. --> Can't edit Unit/ Quantity in Purchase agreement lines. Enter Net amount & Discount percent in in Purchase agreement lines only
Product quantity commitment: You purchase a specific quantity of a product --> Can update Qty and related discount amount and discount percent for Qty in in Purchase agreement lines

Question: "... discounted rate of $3.00 per cable..." --> so It's definitely NO cause Product value commitment doesn't allow to enter Discount amount (rate) and also can't enter quantity for Product value commitment

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You are the purchasing manager at a manufacturing company that makes audio equipment.
You sign an agreement with a vendor to purchase 5,000 speaker cables, item C0001, at a discounted rate of $3.00 per cable. This agreement expires in exactly one year.
You need to set up pricing information and track the fulfillment of the agreement.
Solution:
✑ Create a purchase agreement of type Product value commitment.
✑ Add a line for item C0001.
✑ Enter a product value of $15,000 and enter an expiration date of one year.
Does the solution meet the goal?

discussion.content:
When a quote is created, a prospect is connected. No Opportunity is required or created automatically. And leads are created if a potential customer is identified, but the company is not yet a customer. Opportunities are potential sales to existing customers. Taking that in consideration, the answers should be b-prospect,d-customer,a-lead.
Anyone?
Prospect, Customer, Lead

comments.content:
Accidently upvoted this. Answer is not correct.
Should be prospect, customer, lead

discussion.content: Answer correct
The answer is correct

comments.content:
Opportunities are typically not thought of as "companies" or parties. The lead is the actual company / party. An opportunity might be associated with a company, but they're usually not the same thing.

Of course, your experience may differ.

lead is created by marketing and handed over to sales and if leads meets the qualifications then its converted to opportunity. Opportunity is converted to customer when the quote is confirmed.
so the answer is the right

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You need to configure the system to support regional sales requirements.
Which group assignments should you use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content:
I think we all agree how poorly worded this is.

First, D365 uses "customer group" and "item group" in different ways based on the context. They have distinct meanings outside of commissions, but within commissions, they are also used with a unique meanings. 

However, within commissions, they use multiple terms for each. Regarding customers, they variously call it the "commission customer group" and the "customer group;" similarly with items, it is called the "commission group" "item group" or the "commission item group."

Examples:

1. Commission item group: see the menu item. Commission group: see the field on the released product. Item group: see the tooltip within the commission calculation form on the item code.
2. Commission customer group: see the menu item. Commission group: see the field on the customer.

...

In conclusion, I don't think anyone can make an airtight case.

For Q1 and Q2, the groups are called Commission Customer group and Commission Item group. They are assigned to Commission group field on Customers and Items records. It is a bit misleading, but the answers are correct.

discussion.content:
It should be commission group for both customer & item (Q1 & Q3). On the customer record, there is a field called Commission group. On the released product record, there is also a field called Commission group. Customer group and Item group are already fields used for other purposes on these forms. Since the question is asking about the specific object/form, it should be commission group for these two.

Sales group for sales reps is correct.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/supply-chain/sales-marketing/tasks/set-up-sales-commission-rules.
hence 'commission group' for the third question
